job_title: Research Assistant in South Bend, IN
pros: Flexible, kind, firm, smart, challenging in a good way
cons: s a research assistant, you'll have the opportunity to work alongside some of the brightest minds in your field and gain invaluable insights and knowledge that will help you grow as a researcher. Additionally, Notre Dame values its research assistants and provides them with a supportive and collaborative working environment. You'll have access to state-of-the-art facilities and resources to help you conduct your research and achieve your goals. Furthermore, the University of Notre Dame is located in a beautiful and historic city with a rich cultural heritage. South Bend, Indiana offers a low cost of living compared to other major cities in the US, and you'll have access to a range of outdoor activities, restaurants, and cultural events to enjoy in your downtime. Finally, working as a research assistant at Notre Dame can open up a range of opportunities for your future career. You'll be part of a network of accomplished researchers and scholars who can serve as references and help you advance your career in academia or industry. Overall, working as a research assistant at the University of Notre Dame is a unique and rewarding experience that can set you on a path to success in your chosen field.

job_title: Custodian in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
* Work life balance.
* There are some really great people working team level and a few good people in management.
* Atmosphere is generally positive.
*The Health and Wellness Center is probably the best thing about this job! Excellent benefits through them.
cons:
* Pay was low. With so many opportunities in factory work, it hardly makes sense to work here to pay your bills - great for easy work while simultaneously earning a degree though.
* Advancement was conditional to hoop jumping. No big deal most of the time, but they considered their management certificate more valuable than a technical bachelor's degree.
* Short staffed and high turnover. I felt like I was training people just to watch them quit.
*York Risk Services Group, Inc. - I don't know if ND still uses them but numerous team members had terrible experiences with insurance, FMLA, and short term disability claims that we were told to take by upper management that in turn left us in financial hardship when we initially requested to simply return to work.

review_title: Econ Dept - Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities
job_title: Research Assistant in South Bend, IN
pros: The economists you are able to work with internally and externally are fantastic, kind, generous people, willing to teach you an incredible amount about their research. Highly interesting and rewarding research. Good experience for predoc.
cons: Every full-time RA at LEO was working 60-80 hours per week. Management knew very well, and for the most part ignored the situation, or would state that the workload would get lighter eventually. One RA left after working months of 80 hours a week, confiding in the other RAs that they had to leave for mental health reasons, but of course told management a much "better" reason for leaving, in hopes of getting references, etc. Econ Departments at universities across the US know they can abuse RAs like this because they want to get into grad schools, and LEO was no exception to this. Do not work here as an RA unless you're willing to work 60+ hours a week for no overtime pay. Go for the NGO or consulting industry instead, where the organization will be held to a higher standard of work-life balance. South Bend is overcast and gloomy all winter, so you'll dodge that bullet too.

job_title: Resident Assistant (RA) in San Antonio, TX
pros: Being an RA at ND provides an excellent opportunity to give back to your hall community, to not only get to know your section/hall residents but to form a unique and rewarding relationship with them. Some of the "hard" parts of the job, emotionally counseling and resolving disputes between residents, allow you to learn about and help people in a way that is hard to find elsewhere. Overall, I am immensely grateful for my time as an RA at ND.
cons: The other hard parts of the job are cleaning up puke and writing people up - these parts are not rewarding and are no fun at all. I am also aware that women halls in general expect more of a time commitment from their RAs as well as a stricter enforcement of rules. This disparity is unfair, and I think I would have enjoyed the job less under these conditions. I think my pros apply to both men's and women's halls, but the difference in standards is definitely a con.

review_title: Notre Dame Campus Dining/Catering Use as a Stepping Stone ONLY!!
job_title: Cook II in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
You can say you work for Notre Dame and people think it’s cool. It looks good on a resume.
Great to say you worked there for a year or 2 but don’t go in thinking it’s going to be a life time career or you will get a ruse awaking!!
cons:
They claim they care about you, that you are loved, respected and that they care about your opinion.......but it’s all lies!
It’s not what you know, but who you know that gets you promotions.
You better cut your deal on pay when you walk in the door, because you won’t get anywhere with yearly raises! In 6 years the most I got was a 3.5% yearly raise, which barely covered cost of living and insurance rate increases. This year they gave out 2.5 % and some got less than a 10 cent increase for the entire year.
You will be overworked and underpaid. If you know what you are doing and are willing to do more to pick up the slack, they will allow you to do the extra work with no acknowledgement while other so as little as possible.
ND claims to have a $54,000 benefits package. What you get is the basics......health insurance and dental which you can get anywhere you work!
They have a tuition reimbursement but when you work on food service they aren’t going to let you take a culinary class in the middle of the day!
They have college tuition for your kids but don’t tell you you have to work there 5 years before your kids are eligible unless you read the handbook cover to cover. So if you get hired and your kid is a senior in high school, they will have graduated before you have worked long enough to apply for tuition reimbursement lol!

I worked there for almost 20 years, when I started there was more than enough staff to get everything accomplished- even when serving an average of 10,000 meals a day. review_title: Guest Services Associate - The Morris Inn
job_title: Guest Service Associate in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
I worked at the Front Desk of The Morris Inn for 3 years while in college. (This review only pertains to The Morris Inn - the hotel on campus) I loved that job. You meet amazing people and management listens and shows you that you are appreciated. They occasionally hand out small gifts or bring food just to say “thank you”. The benefits are remarkable from the university, although I was never considered ‘full time’ in order to take advantage of them. 
There was plenty of opportunity to pick up shifts or work between positions within The Morris Inn
cons: Often understaffed so you will be asked to fill in for shifts every week or two. It’s hard to find quality employees for the $11 an hour and over-hiring would create the need for employees to find a second job during the slow times (Christmas Break). So it’s a tough balance for management to make.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor, Mathematics in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
Great job, great environment, great ambiance, great facilities and beautiful campus. 

The very, very must: awesome students! Motivated, hard working, they have personality, a good sense of humor and are a lots of fun. It's just such a great pleasure to teach!

Also, I'm a quite liberal, total atheist. The religious affiliation has never been a problem at all. Most people, especially students and staff, are catholic, as many people all around the globe are. I'm open minded and very respectful of other's opinions and beliefs. And you learn a lot from it. I always consider that aspect of Notre Dame as a plus. 

I should mention salary and benefits are pretty good too.
cons:
Not always a lot of freedom regarding the way to organize certain courses (content and planning). You often work with a team for such or such course. In particular, some courses use online HW, which requires the whole team to remain synchronized. It reduces the possibility: to adapt the speed of your lecture; to include some digressions or topics of your own choice, which affects a little your teaching creativity and pedagogy. 

Some might say South Bend is a little boring, but Chicago is 80 miles away....

job_title: Associate Director of Finance in Notre Dame, IN
pros: Beautiful campus, daily Mass, good benefits, Christmas shutdown that doesn’t count against your vacation.  ND will be around for a long time.  The students are great.  Lots of events on campus.
cons: Staff pay is usually okay, but not great.  Raises have been low (2% or less).  Parking is the big joke.  HR is not great.  A big problem is that some faculty are given supervisory responsibilities over staff, but they are not trained nor evaluated on supervision.  Plus they rotate out, usually after 3 years, so just when they finally figure things out, they leave, and you start over again with someone who knows next to nothing.  HR has no control over faculty, only staff, so staff are treated differently from faculty in a lot of ways.  Lots of construction on campus, but new buildings have windows that don’t open and thermostats that can’t be adjusted.  Maintenance and custodial staff are stretched thin.

review_title: Notre Dame is just like your family...a lot of love there but also a little dysfunctional.
job_title: Director-level in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
Great benefits, offer 50% tuition benefit to children of employees.
Overall solid leadership, a place you will be proud to work, an organization that tries to do the "right thing" at all times.
Impressive brand.
If you are an ND Football fan you will be in heaven.  Nice discount on tickets and solid access to ticket through campus network.
Great place for someone at the end of their career to work (45+).
cons:
Old school.  Probably about 25 years behind in terms of treatment and promotion of women.
Slow to act (but I believe this is a characteristic of institutions of higher learning.)
Does not deal with low performers.  I have reflected on this a lot.  I think it is because 1) they know they are the main employer in the area and they have compassion for people (ie.  if they fire someone, that person would likely be looking at a relocation) and 2) the tuition benefit (again compassion for the employee (even if they suck) who has a child in school.)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Notre Dame, IN
pros: This is one of the best university in US. For a student, the school and university are very good. They respect students, care about you and they are professional and supportive. We have the best information manage system (inside ND), very good dining hall and campus environment. For a staff or faculty member, I would say the working condition/environment are much better than other top ranking universities. I have been to other TOP schools (such as MIT), they may do better research, however, I would choose to work at Notre Dame if I can get a position here. Check out the office room space, lab conditions, they are amazing. Besides, very good culture, good sport, good book store, they are running a prime brand successfully, it's called ND!
cons: As a graduate, we all know that your boss is also very important when you are picking a school (even more important than the quality of the school sometime). So just be cautious, I'm not saying Notre Dame is not good, but there are better. Depend on your interests.

review_title: One of the best Universities to work for in the world
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Notre Dame, IN
pros: Great people, great work-environment, and great benefits...and a pretty good football team to boot.  Working at Notre Dame you interact on a daily basis with highly skilled and qualified individuals.  As part of the University system, you are constantly facing new challenges and objectives that make each day different than the last.  We also get some of the best benefits of any company I've worked for.  Discounts around town and around the country in addition to access to many Notre Dame amenities, just to name a few.
cons: The University is spread out and employs a number of different people who have been at the University for varying times.  Some of the old guard does not like change and it can sometimes take forever to get any meaningful change done at work.  But that's the case for lots of places - certainly nothing unique to Notre Dame.

review_title: Good benefits, but lacking in other areas

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Bend, IN

review_title: Notre Dame,  not all is golden
job_title: Operations Manager in Notre Dame, IN
pros: Most of the students here are great people,  that is,  until they graduate.
cons: The University treats exempt staff far better than they treat non-exempt staff.  Low level management often say "if you don't like it, leave" as opposed to trying to fix a problem.  Poor equipment quality to work with,  unless you are faculty or student.  Mid to Low level management is like a "good ol boys club".

review_title: Best Place in Michiana to Work For
job_title: Associate Research Programmer in Notre Dame, IN
pros: Good benefits.  Are they the best?  No.  But they are some of the best benefits you will find St. Joseph County.  Great benefits for your family and children.  They are also very lenient.  In my department I get a flexible schedule, can work from home sometimes, and they expect you to know what you are doing and get it done.  I don't have management hovering over my shoulder, and they give me a lot of room to solve my own problems, make my own mistakes, and make decisions for myself.  Everyone seems friendly.  They put a lot into your hiring process through HR, and are willing to put a lot into their employees to keep them educated and happy.
cons:
The educational benefits are good, but they don't tell you right away that you have to pay taxes on those benefits, which those "taxes" can be more expensive than even taking classes at another in-state public University.  Is it still a big discount off the normal tuition for a Notre Dame education?  Yes.  Is it still expensive for a new employee that isn't faculty?  Too expensive.  

I mentioned before that the work environment is lenient and you spend a lot of time working on your own.  This can be a good thing, but sometimes it can be bad.  Since I am a new employee, I feel that I need some direction and assistance getting things done or understanding my work load.  I don't really get any direction at all sometimes, which can be discouraging.  There is a campus-wide employee review system that seems great at first, but still falls short in actually giving you useful feedback from managers in regards to job performance.  Sometimes I wonder if they just don't like me, or if I am doing a good job, or what is going on.  I can spend days wondering what my next steps are on a project before they get back to me.  I can even email, or call in sick, and not even receive a response to make sure that the message was received or approved.

review_title: No different than any other university
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
Salary is fairly high compared to cost of living.

The university has a lot of resources available for research, but you may never know about them since there's no training.
cons:
Notre Dame pretends to be different from other secular universities; it is not. They care primarily about money. There is nothing that distinguishes them.

Grad school is like a 1,000 little LLC's. Everything is up to your advisor, which can be good or bad depending on your advisor, but there is no support from the university and higher levels or even the department.

You are essentially on your own with no formal training  or guidelines from others unless some other group member provides it by mere happenstance.

job_title: Feet On the Ground in Notre Dame, IN
pros:
Educational benefit for employees children is one of the best.  Full health care coverage with different levels of payment options available.  Decent vacation structure depending on your status (exempt vs non-exempt)
Campus atmosphere like no other, students, staff and faculty are very friendly.
Learning at work degree program for staff eligible.
Faculty & Staff eligible to purchase season tickets to all sports (limit of 2 seats)
cons:
What was once a family-first institution is now run more like a business.  Raises are pitiful (usually 3% or less).  Benefit costs rise yearly while perks are phased out.  When the season ticket option for staff & faculty was initially offered it was in lieu of a yearly raise, cost was low enough that even hourly people could afford to purchase them.  The campus needed more money so the discount afforded to staff & faculty was removed (20%)  in what is being seen by those affected as a way to get staff & faculty to quit buying them. Cost now is over $1000 a season which for most is too exorbitant.
Hourly wages are meager thus if you have children and need day-care you are working just to pay insurance and day-care costs, you'll need a second job to make it.
As people retire, there is a reluctance to  replace them but the buildings continue to be built and the work continues to double and everyone is expected to get the work done with the resources available
Tuition reimbursement for employees is below par

review_title: ECDC- Not as great as they may seem.

review_title: Worked part-time as a research assistant

review_title: Millennial hemorrhaging and questionable management decisions abound
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Bend, IN
pros:
Ahh Notre Dame. The prestige! The football! The Catholic tradition! Notre Dame certainly has some things going for it. When I applied for other jobs most other employers were impressed because of the name recognition. The benefits package is also solid and the work-life balance is good. Living in South Bend is cheap..if you can stomach how boring it is. 

There is a lot of internal mobility- it's much easier to get hired internally than it is externally and employees often take advantage of this. There is also a rotational program that I've heard good things about.
cons:
Unless you work in development, the pay is abysmal. 

Notre Dame is hemorrhaging young adult employees. If you're not married, or married with a child on the way, there is nothing for you in South Bend. Yes, it's getting better- I'm serious, it is! But it's still 5 years away from actually being worth living here. Of all of the younger employees I've met (30 and below), 85% of them left within two years. 

Additionally, management is HARDLY responsive to problems in the workplace. Everyone in my office went through every communication channel possible to let management know that our boss was absolutely terrible to us and terrible for the university and nothing has been done. Every single employee of the department has now left. I wish this was an isolated case, but I've heard similar stories throughout campus- including those about Title IX concerns.  

The culture is also exceedingly slow. Everything here seems to take at least six months. Getting a form signed by someone can take two weeks. It took 3.5 months to hire me, and that was a relatively efficient hiring. If you're looking for an easy place to clock in, push some papers around and then leave at 5, this is it.
